item.title: Importing New Emotes, Textures, Graphics, AND MORE!
item.dc:creator: @wolfs_goal wolfs goal
item.description:
@wolfs_goal wrote:

[quote=“badger41, post:29, topic:337484”][quote author=wolfs goal link=topic=433885.msg3189993#msg3189993 date=1272152435]

BAHAHAHAHAHA. You are retarded. Your doing it all wrong.

No, Actually, I just finished dumping the 603 Cache I packed the newer GFX into the client. Now working on Emotes and NPC’S
[/quote]

pardon my skepticism, but can we see proof of this?[/quote]

There really isn’t much proof to see mate, new GFX isn’t much…

When I finish the emote dump, I’ll post a video of new emotes such as, dungeoneering emote and some others.

Or if I finish the NPC dump, I’ll just do emote dump with this so you can see fully animated, not half assed monsters.

item.dc:creator: @glestrts glestrts
item.description:
@glestrts wrote:

cocoa:

Wouldn’t it just be easier to move up to the revision above and change the packet id’s used serverside?

it would be easier for “you”, but if everyone else wanted to use it they would have to change their servers aswell, so although this takes longer for one person its faster for the masses.

Read full topic
item.source: Importing New Emotes, Textures, Graphics, AND MORE!

item.title: Importing New Emotes, Textures, Graphics, AND MORE!
item.dc:creator: @wolfs_goal wolfs goal
item.description:
@wolfs_goal wrote:

Moparisthebest:

A better thing to do would be to convert a newer cache to an older format, or add a few things from a newer cache to an older one. That way you don’t need to change a client to add different things to it, it’s what the client was written to do. Also you could load your custom cache into moparscape.

I guess I could do this, It does seem a bit easier. Possibly now I’ll be able to see why some emotes have gone blank, like they aren’t even there anymore it seems o.o

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @glestrts glestrts
item.description:
@glestrts wrote:

Moparisthebest:

A better thing to do would be to convert a newer cache to an older format, or add a few things from a newer cache to an older one. That way you don’t need to change a client to add different things to it, it’s what the client was written to do. Also you could load your custom cache into moparscape.

agreed, it would make it more useable rather than having to rewrite/change nearly every line of code in the client that deals with reading and using data from the cache.

item.source: Importing New Emotes, Textures, Graphics, AND MORE!

item.title: Importing New Emotes, Textures, Graphics, AND MORE!
item.dc:creator: @wolfs_goal wolfs goal
item.description:
@wolfs_goal wrote:

[quote=“glestrts, post:8, topic:337484”][quote author=badger41 link=topic=433885.msg3186549#msg3186549 date=1271808761]
in theory, if you get all the emotes working while having the 459 cache on a 317 client (thats what i suppose you are using, correct me if im wrong)
couldnt you just do the same modifications to make hard coded emotes work for a client using the 317 or 377 cache?

im not saying 1 is better than the other, just wondering.

[/quote]
yes, which is why i dont quite understand this. you first need to make the client compatable with the new files and then load them, rather than the other way around[/quote]

Okay, so I will clear this question up a bit…

Instead of marking up our client with files that are useless, we could all end up loading the same cache. Just having different methods.

Wouldn’t it be nice if we could get a 317 client to load a 602 cache? Even higher possibly. Using a SQL system, not saying I know much about SQL, but still, if we upload the cache versions to a database, or to a VPS, couldn’t we have clients load cache from there?

Like seriously, instead of packing class20/animation.java full of emote codes, why not just put a bit more hard coding into it and make class20/animation.java load the cache’s emotes.

If you put enough thought into this, you will come up with this conclusion.

Making a 317 load any cache version, depending on what the player/server owner wants to use, we can eliminate emote systems and all the bull shit, of my server has this and others don’t please do not leech.

We would all end up using the same files that load different cache’s. I already have this method working properly for all 474 emotes, graphics, and models.

Now, I am going through the server sided portion of this and changing the emotes that were set to 317 to a 459. This way no emotes are fucked up. Also, changing graphics.

Here’s what I saw in my client.

With Swats Emote System and overloaded files full of custom animation code: 72.4MB
With the new system of new cache loading files an d the 474 cache: 42MB

It’s not that much, but still. When you make an update now, all you really have to do is just zip your client.java and your done. I say this because there will be no need for custom emotes/graphics/models/map data if we can load newer versions of cache.

Not to be rude or anything, but I see more and more leeching happening. We should be more concerned about what your server has rather than client. YAY! YOUR CLIENT HAS A MUSIC PLAYER, PUT YOUR MUSIC INTO A FOLDER THEN VIGOROUSLY CLICK NEXT TO FIND THE SONG YOU WANT! Wait, isn’t this the purpose of WMP or Playlist or Youtube? Also, SWEET! CUSTOM INTERFACE! Who cares? It’s just text and that’s about it, most interfaces are for the newer interfaces on runescape.

So as I was saying, the client would have no need for anything custom rather than the name and the client background…

And for the last guy that posted, I modified class36(emote file main) And my SpotAnim(GFX’S) And Lastly my RSInterface(Interfaces) Java code and made it compatible with 459 and 474 cache. I am working on the server sided part now, A.K.A the part were we start changing standing and attacking emote ID’s.

Read full topic
item.source: Importing New Emotes, Textures, Graphics, AND MORE!
